
An impatient hacker reused a nonce when signing two blockchain transactions. Recover the secret key from their signatures and ciphertext: Sig1: c050c3f0b8d45b9e093a91cb96d097b24100e66585d0d8561e01c1231837493ff6129c0c9cdf60331ff57af5c30a07de4b0494cdf0db980575aac929d97c7584
Sig2: c050c3f0b8d45b9e093a91cb96d097b24100e66585d0d8561e01c1231837493fe00a7f8009921bc1b35e292556823eee53046922f908728c4bee8db1f919736c


Public Key (x,y): (28395899215184736746150495505697413128449996799294618065179244743183853856503, 100002270668643638373264692751395695727051096988298615585736083457867023513016)
Messages:
1. CTF challenge message
2. Second signed message
Curve: secp256k1The flag format is flag{hex(private_key)}

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{10c19bb6f7757836958c5153e2e1b7fa9e0d5bb18e71acd1b4cdd7f33f5e8795}
ciphertext: Sig1: c050c3f0b8d45b9e093a91cb96d097b24100e66585d0d8561e01c1231837493ff6129c0c9cdf60331ff57af5c30a07de4b0494cdf0db980575aac929d97c7584

cipher: ECDSA Nonce Reuse
hint: Identical nonce usage breaks ECDSA security. What's common between the signatures?
necessary_info: Public Key (x,y): (28395899215184736746150495505697413128449996799294618065179244743183853856503, 100002270668643638373264692751395695727051096988298615585736083457867023513016)
